disease.desc: Meningiomas are one of the principal primary brain tumours in adults accounting, for up to 37\% of all primary brain tumours. Primary meningioma tumours of the central nervous system are the third most common tumours in men and the sixth most common tumour in women between ages 35 to 49. Meningiomas originate from the cells located in the meningeal membrans of the brain and spinal cord. Evidence for an inherited predisposition to meningioma is convincingly provided by rare genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis type 2, Werner syndrome and Gorlin syndrome. \newline \newline The two to three-fold elevated risk of meningioma in the relatives of patients with meningioma also demonstrates that the disease has associated genetic risk. Genes implicated in meningioma are associated with oxidative stress, which can be explained by the fact that brain tumours have high oxygen consumption. 92\% of meningiomas are benign, with 8\% being either atypical or malignant. Many individuals have meningiomas but remain asymptomatic for their entire life. As many as 1 – 2\% of all post-mortem brain examinations reveal meningiomas that were unknown to during the individual’s lifetime. The five-year survival rate for meningioma is 70\% for benign, 75\% for atypical and 55\% for malignant grades respectively.

disease.name: Nasopharyngeal Cancer
disease.desc: Nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC) is a mucosal epithelium-originated malignancy of the nasopharynx. It is a multifactorial cancer associated with risks from both genetic and environmental factors. NPC incidence shows geographic and ethnic distribution being more prominent in the Southeast Asian regions, including southern China, Malaysia and Taiwan. The annual incidence rate is over 25-fold higher than that observed in the Western world. The World Health Organisation has defined three types of NPC. Type 2b is the most common type and is clinically defined as a non-keratinising undifferentiated form. This type is consistently associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, and the EBV DNA sequence is detectable in tumours from patients in endemic areas. Other risks include consumption of pickled food and exposure to noxious inhalants. The EBV association is mainly observed in individuals of Chinese origin suggesting that additional genetic factors act in concert with environmental factors such as EBV to regulate NPC tumour formation and progression. \newline \newline NPC is ranked based on clinical stages upon diagnosis, ranging from small tumours confined to the nasopharynx (stage I) through to large tumours showing bilateral neck disease, intracranial invasion and distant metastasis (stage IV). Most patients are diagnosed when their tumours have reached stage III or IV. The five-year survival rate for NPC ranges from 98\% for stage I through to 73\% for stage IV.

disease.name: Neuroblastoma
disease.desc: Neuroblastoma is the most common solid cancer of early childhood; 50\% of neuroblastoma cases occur in children younger than two years old. Neuroblastoma is an embryonal cancer; it is thought to arise from partially committed primordial cells during foetal or early childhood development. Neuroblastoma arises from neural crest elements of the sympathetic nervous system, and most frequently originates in one of the adrenal glands. However, it can also develop in nerve tissues in the neck, chest or abdomen. Approximately 50\% of neuroblastoma cases show an aggressive clinical course with widespread metastases to bone and bone marrow at diagnosis. Cure rates remain less than 40\% and survivors often have serious lifelong coexisting conditions. Neuroblastoma remains an important clinical problem, accounting for 15\% of deaths attributable to malignant conditions in children. The five-year survival rate for neuroblastoma ranges from 95\% for the lowest risk groups to just 35\% for the high-risk aggressive forms of the disease.

disease.name: Oral And Throat Cancers
disease.desc: Head and neck cancers, which include cancers that occur in the oral cavity, pharynx, and larynx, are the sixth most common type of cancers. All head and neck cancers are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN). The cancers originate from the mucosal lining (epithelium) of their regions. Although smoking and alcohol consumption are known as major risk factors for SCCHN, only a few smokers and drinkers develop SCCHN, suggesting that there is genetic susceptibility to this disease in the general population. Head and neck cancers often spread to the lymph nodes of the neck. This is often the first sign of the disease at the time of diagnosis. Other risk factors for head and neck cancers include betel nut chewing and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. In particular, HPV16 can be detected in many or most tumour samples tested. The five-year survival prognosis depends on the site of infection. This can range from 95\% for early stage nasopharyngeal cancer, 80\% for early stage lip cancer and 60 – 70\% for early stage nose and sinus cancers. Late stage detection of a cancer has a five-year survival of between 15 - 30\% regardless of the site of tumour.

disease.name: Ovarian Cancer
disease.desc: Epithelial carcinoma of the ovary is one of the most common gynecological malignancies and one of the most lethal cancers in women. Family history is the greatest risk factor for ovarian cancer. Compared with a 1.6\% lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer in the general population, women having one first-degree relative with ovarian cancer have a 5\% increased risk. Environmental and genetic factors contribute to this increased risk, but studies of twins suggest that genetic factors are more important. Ovarian cancer is hormone-related and evidence supports a protective role for progesterone in the etiology of the disease. The protective effect increases steadily with each birth as pregnancy is associated with high progesterone levels. Oral contraceptives are also protective against ovarian cancer. \newline \newline Data from large population studies indicate an increased risk of ovarian cancer in women with endometriosis. Symptoms are initially subtle and are easily confused with other illnesses. Ovarian cancer is associated with high mortality because it lacks early detection or screening. This means that more than 60\% of cases are diagnosed when they have reached advanced stages I.e. the tumour has already spread beyond the ovaries. The five-year survival rate for all stages of ovarian cancer is 47\%; this increases to almost 93\% if the tumour is detected and treated in its earliest stage.

disease.name: Pancreatic Cancer
disease.desc: Pancreatic cancer has one of the highest mortality rates among all the cancers, with death rates approaching its incidence rates. The five-year relative survival rate for pancreatic cancer remains less than 5\%. There is no commercial screening test for this malignancy, and by the time of initial diagnosis, metastatic disease is commonly present. Pancreatic cancer is the thirteenth most common cancer in the world. Medically, pancreatic cancer is defined as a malignant neoplasm originating from transformed cells arising in pancreatic tissues. 95\% of the pancreatic cancers are defined as adenocarcinomas. \newline \newline Approximately 10\% of pancreatic cancer patients have family history of the disease, and individuals having first-degree relatives with pancreatic cancer revealed a two to four-fold higher risk of the disease when compared to the general population. Other established risk factors or pancreatic cancer include having a medical history of type 2 diabetes, being overweight – having an elevated body-mass index, and cigarette smoking. Studies have also suggested an increased risk of pancreatic cancer within families with hereditary pancreatitis – the inflammation of pancreas. Most patients with pancreatic cancer experience back pain, weight loss, or jaundice. Clinical depression can also be a symptom. Typically, pancreatic cancer spreads to regional lymph nodes, and later to the liver and or to the peritoneal cavity.

disease.name: Prostate Cancer
disease.desc: Prostate cancer (Pca) is one of the most commonly diagnosed cancers in men. It is a form of cancer that develops in the prostate gland of the male reproductive system. The incidence of Pca is known to be much lower in Asian men than in Western men. The number of Pca cases is, however, growing rapidly in the developed areas of the Asian region, and a four-fold increase has been observed in the last three decades in Shanghai. More than 30 prostate cancer risk-associated loci have been identified in populations of European descent. Many of these markers are also significantly associated with a risk of Pca in Asian men. \newline \newline Age, race, family history of prostate cancer, and obesity are well-established risk factors for Pca. Individuals having a first-degree relative affected by the disease are 2.5 times more likely to develop the disease themselves. Pca is rare in men under the age of 45 and the median age at diagnosis is 70. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is a robust clinical biomarker for the developing disease although it is estimated that half of the men who test positive during screening will only develop a benign (not life threatening) form of the disease. Early prostate cancer usually causes no symptoms but a third of individuals may experience difficulties in urination that could include blood, painful urination or flow issues. Sexual dysfunction may also be experienced. The five-year survival rate for prostate cancer, when detected early, can approach 98\%.

disease.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)
disease.desc: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a form of skin cancer. It is a malignancy of the squamous cells, a type of cells that forms the main part of the top layer of the skin. However, squamous cells also occur in the lining of the digestive tract, lungs, and other areas of the body. SCC occurs as a form of cancer in diverse tissues, including the lips, mouth, oesophagus, urinary bladder, prostate, lung, vagina, and cervix, among others. Despite all being called squamous cell carcinoma, SCCs of different body sites can show tremendous differences in presented symptoms, natural history, prognosis and response to treatment. \newline \newline Human papilloma virus (HPV) has been associated with SCC of the oropharynx, lung, fingers and ano-genital region. Sunlight exposure and immunosuppression are risk factors for SCC of the skin, with chronic sun exposure being the strongest environmental risk factor. The long-term outcome of SCC is dependent primarily upon several factors: the sub-type of the carcinoma, location and severity. The long-term outcome is positive with less than 4\% of SCC cases having a risk of metastasis.

disease.name: Stomach Cancer
disease.desc: Stomach cancer is estimated to be the fourth most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide with 700,000 people dying from this malignancy annually. The most common cancers of the stomach are adenocarcinomas but other histological types have also been reported. Multiple environmental and lifestyle factors are found to be associated with risk for stomach cancer, including a diet lacking in fresh fruits and vegetables, excessive intake of salt, tobacco smoking, alcohol consumption, and Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. H. pylori is the major acquired etiological agent responsible for stomach cancer, although only a small proportion (> 3\%) of infected individuals develop the cancer. Prevalence of H. pylori infections range from 40 – 80 \% in humans. \newline \newline Stomach cancer shows a male predominance in its incidence with three times as many men developing the disease compared to women. Estrogen may provide protection against the cancer for women. Stomach cancer is often asymptomatic, or has non-specific symptoms in its early stages. When the disease is diagnosed it is typically at a more advanced stage and may already spread to distal tissues. The five-year survival rate varies from 70\% for the early detection of low-grade tumours to just 4\% for the most advanced metastatic tumours.

disease.name: Testicular Germ-cell Tumor
disease.desc: Testicular germ cell tumours (TGCT) have a peak incidence among those aged 25 – 34 years. Most TGCTs in adults are malignant with a strong propensity to metastasise. Incidence varies widely across racial groups, with a five-fold lower rate among African-American males in the United States. Prevalence varies from 9.2 per 100,000 in Denmark to 0.2 per 100,000 in Algeria. \newline \newline Familial incidents of TGCT are well documented and family history is the strongest known risk factor. The first-degree relatives of TGCT-affected males have a 5 to 19-fold increased risk if a brother is affected, or a 2 to 4-fold increased risk if the father is affected. Other risk factors for TGCT include cryptorchidism (undescended testicles), subfertility, and race. Testicular cancer has one of the highest cure rates of all cancers, especially if treated before metastasis. The five-year survival rate for TGCT is 99\% if the tumour has not spread, or 72\% if it has spread to distal lymph nodes or organs. One of the first signs of testicular cancer is often a lump or swelling in the testes that may be accompanied by pain or aches, breast enlargement and lower back pain.

disease.name: Thyroid Cancer
disease.desc: Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common malignant tumour in endocrine organs and represents approximately 85\% of all thyroid cancers. It is a complex disease with a largely unknown etiology. Its only well-known environmental risk factor is exposure to ionising radiation. Genetic polymorphisms have been shown to contribute to individual susceptibility to PTC. The incidence of PTC in industrialised countries has been rising over the past few decades. At present, its incidence is 4.9 and 14.1 per 100,000 in the United States for males and females of European ancestry respectively. The risk of thyroid cancer has a greater genetic component than the familial risk for any other cancer, and the effect has even been shown to extend beyond the nuclear family. The risk is highest for first-degree male relatives of affected male individuals but lowest for first-degree female relatives of affected female individuals. \newline \newline Risk factors for thyroid cancer include deficiency in iodine intake, exposure to ionising radiation and nodular disease of the thyroid. Often the first symptom of thyroid cancer is a nodule in the thyroid region of the neck. The five-year survival rate for thyroid cancer is almost 100\% for low stage tumours, and drops to 50\% for later stage tumours with metastases.
